questions.question: Who is a vet?

options.text: A doctor for animals and birds

questions.answer: A doctor for animals and birds

questions.question: Why must a vet have wide knowledge?

options.text: Because animals have different body structures

questions.answer: Because animals have different body structures

questions.question: Which animal is refusing her milk?
Why is the dog not eating his bone?
Which bird does nothing but groan?
Why are ducks and chickens failing to lay?
What problem does the centipede have?
Which animal is suffering from heat?
Which animal has not stirred for several years?
Which animal eats paper bags and chokes?
Why does the poet call the vet ‘omniscient’?

options.text: Because he knows everything about animals

questions.answer: Because he knows everything about animals

questions.question: What is the poet’s advice to the youth?

options.text: To earn a living an easier way

questions.answer: To earn a living an easier way

questions.question: What is the main theme of the poem 'The Bees' by William Shakespeare?
questions.answer: The organized social structure of honey bees and the lessons it teaches human society.

questions.question: Which field of work does a Chief Minister belong to?
Which field of work does a Magistrate belong to?
Which field of work does a Soldier belong to?
Which field of work does a Trader belong to?
Which field of work does a Builder belong to?
Which field of work does a Driver belong to?
Which field of work does a Teacher belong to?
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a lark.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a snail.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a giraffe.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a bee.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as an elephant.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a mouse.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as an eel.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a fox.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a worm.
Complete the comparison: as _____ as a deer.
What does the word 'sorts' mean in the poem?
What are 'magistrates' in the context of the poem?
questions.answer: Civil officers who administer the law.

questions.question: What does 'venture' mean in the line about merchant bees?
questions.answer: To take up a new project involving risk.

questions.question: What does 'make boot upon' mean?
questions.answer: Begin to collect around or plunder.

questions.question: What does 'pillage' mean?
Where does the emperor-bee sit?
What does the emperor-bee do?
questions.answer: He surveys the activities of the bees in his kingdom.

questions.question: What does 'busied' mean?
What does 'kneading' mean?
What do 'roofs of gold' refer to?
questions.answer: The honeycombs built by the mason bees.

questions.question: What does 'surly' mean?
What does 'delivering' mean in the poem?
What are 'executors'?
questions.answer: Persons who carry out a death sentence.

questions.question: What is a 'drone'?
questions.answer: A male bee that does no work.

questions.question: What is the role of the king/emperor bee in the hive?
questions.answer: To supervise and survey all activities in the hive.

questions.question: What do magistrate bees do?
questions.answer: They correct or maintain order within the hive.

questions.question: What do merchant bees do?
questions.answer: They venture trade abroad, collecting nectar from flowers.

questions.question: What do soldier bees do?
questions.answer: They are armed with stings and protect the hive or collect nectar.

questions.question: What do mason bees do?
questions.answer: They build the honeycombs ('roofs of gold').

questions.question: What do civilian bees do?
questions.answer: They knead (make) the honey from nectar.

questions.question: What do porter bees do?
questions.answer: They carry heavy burdens (nectar/pollen) into the hive.

questions.question: What does the judge bee do?
questions.answer: It delivers the lazy drone to executors for punishment.

questions.question: What can human beings learn from honey bees?
questions.answer: How to lead an organized nation.

questions.question: What do soldier bees carry home?
What does the emperor-bee supervise the building of?
Which bees make honey from nectar?
Why is the drone given a death sentence?
questions.answer: Because it does not do any work.

questions.question: Complete the phrase: _____ march.
Complete the phrase: _____ tent.
Complete the phrase: _____ masons.
Complete the phrase: _____ porters.
Complete the phrase: _____ burdens.
Complete the phrase: _____ executors.
What is alliteration?
questions.answer: The repetition of the same consonant sound at the beginning of words in a line.

questions.question: Give an example of an alliterative line from the poem.
questions.answer: 'The singing masons building roofs of gold' (repetition of 's' and 'b' sounds).

questions.question: What is onomatopoeia?
questions.answer: A word that imitates the sound it represents.

questions.question: Which line in the poem contains an onomatopoeic word?
questions.answer: 'The sad eyed Justice, with his surly hum' – 'hum' imitates the sound of bees.

questions.question: Pick a line that creates an image of bees busy at work.
questions.answer: 'The civil citizens kneading up the honey'.

questions.question: What is stress in pronunciation?
questions.answer: The extra force used when pronouncing a syllable in a word.

questions.question: In the word 'king-dom', which syllable is stressed?
How is stress marked in phonetic transcription?
questions.answer: With a short vertical line above the stressed syllable.

questions.question: Mark the stress in the word 'creatures'.
Mark the stress in the word 'burden'.
Mark the stress in the word 'mechanic'.
Mark the stress in the word 'executor'.
Mark the stress in the word 'delivering'.
Mark the stress in the word 'magistrate'.
What is the project suggested at the end of the chapter?
questions.answer: To gather information about insects (Bee, Praying mantis, Butterfly, Beetle, Wasp, Dragon-fly) and make a file titled 'Insects – our friends'.

questions.question: Name two insects mentioned in the project.
What is the purpose of the project?
questions.answer: To learn about insects and recognize them as friends.

questions.question: What does the poet mean by 'the art of order'?
questions.answer: The skill of maintaining an organized and structured society.

questions.question: How are bees compared to a 'peopled kingdom'?
questions.answer: They have different roles and a hierarchical structure similar to human kingdoms.

questions.question: What are 'velvet buds'?
questions.answer: Soft, delicate flower buds from which bees collect nectar.

questions.question: What is the 'tent royal'?
questions.answer: The beehive, where the emperor bee resides.

questions.question: Why are the porters called 'poor mechanic'?
questions.answer: They perform hard, laborious work of carrying heavy loads.

questions.question: What is the fate of the drone?
questions.answer: It is handed over to executors for death because it is lazy and does not work.

questions.question: What literary device is used in 'singing masons'?
What does the phrase 'sad eyed Justice' refer to?
questions.answer: The judge bee who condemns the drone.

questions.question: What does 'yawning drone' suggest?
questions.answer: The drone is idle and lazy.

questions.question: How does the poem end?
questions.answer: With the drone being delivered to pale executors for punishment.

questions.question: What is the tone of the poem?
What lesson do bees teach humans according to the poem?
questions.answer: The importance of order, duty, and hard work in society.

questions.question: Which bee is described as 'armed in their stings'?
What do bees bring home to the emperor?
What is the emperor bee busy doing?
questions.answer: Surveying his kingdom and the work of the bees.

questions.question: What are 'heavy burdens'?
questions.answer: The loads of nectar and pollen brought by porter bees.

questions.question: What is the 'narrow gate'?
What does 'pale executors' imply?
questions.answer: The bees that carry out the death sentence are grim and solemn.

questions.question: What is the rhyme scheme of the poem?
questions.answer: The poem is in blank verse (unrhymed iambic pentameter).

questions.question: What is the meter of the poem?
Why is the poem titled 'The Bees'?
questions.answer: It describes the social organization and work ethic of bees.

questions.question: What is the moral of the poem?
questions.answer: Society functions well when everyone performs their duty diligently.

questions.question: What does 'merry march' suggest about the soldier bees?
questions.answer: They work cheerfully and with discipline.

questions.question: What does 'civil citizens' refer to?
questions.answer: The worker bees that make honey.

questions.question: What is the role of the 'singing masons'?
questions.answer: They build the honeycombs and are happy in their work.

questions.question: What does 'surly hum' describe?
questions.answer: The grumbling sound of the judge bee.

questions.question: What is the punishment for the drone?
How does the poem relate to human society?
questions.answer: It draws parallels between bee society and human professions and governance.

questions.question: What is the significance of 'roofs of gold'?
questions.answer: It metaphorically describes the valuable honeycombs.

questions.question: What does the poet admire about bees?
questions.answer: Their order, industry, and division of labor.

questions.question: What is the main message of the poem?
questions.answer: Efficiency and order in society come from everyone doing their assigned role.

questions.question: Who is the author of the poem?
